data.title: Inserting Backticks deletes last character of a word

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
(Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these)
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.5 

When adding backticks in front of a written word, and pressing ALT+Right, the last character of the word gets deleted / replaced by a backtick. I'd expect to only add the backtick and not replace the last word

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type a word, afterwards add a ``` ` ``` in front of the word
2. Press `ALT+Right`
Now the cursor jumped two words (instead of just one) and replaces last character of the first word.
![out](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6740568/27473749-7cf64dd0-5800-11e7-825f-50d2fe41db36.gif)

**What is the expected behavior?**
Get `min-height: `, as it happens on [emmet site](https://docs.emmet.io/)

![vscode_insiders_emmet_css_demo](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1856145/27471745-811d223e-5801-11e7-8f1e-8a124865e868.gif)

data.title: Emmet + SCSS = very bad
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (779a7dfa682e31d870680caea572a11d009ab447, 2017-06-23T05:59:57.891Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
Bookmarks|ale|0.15.2
project-manager|ale|0.18.1
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
vscode-great-icons|emm|2.1.8
beautify|Hoo|1.1.1
atom-keybindings|ms-|2.0.1
seti-icons|qin|0.1.3
vscode-icons|rob|7.9.0
---

With yesterday's fixes, Emmet at least doesn't try to put HTML tags into SCSS, this is good.
Now for the (very) bad. Ussing Emmet with SCSS is just very painful.

Say, I type `margin` in SCSS and press TAB. I expect something like `margin: `, instead I get (from Emmet): `max-resolution: ;`

From `border` and TAB I get: `background-origin: padding-box;`

Fom `padding` and TAB I get: `page-break-after: auto;`. This is very bad, on the border of uselessness.

data.title: Goto definition for some functions are taking to the wrong definitions.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: the listing length exceeds browsers' URL characters limit
---

Steps to Reproduce:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8809560/27468003-8e78d848-5819-11e7-873e-cf7c79a0a7d1.png)
This was observed when using fabric in python.
1. In a python file, add 
```
from fabric.contrib.project import rsync_project
from fabric.api import sudo
```
2. Hover the mouse over `rsync_project` or `sudo` or command+click on it to take to the definition. It goes to the definition for host_prompting_wrapper in a different file instead of the definition for sudo or rsync_project. This is not observed for all functions. This is observed for a very limited set of functions.

data.title: [html] base not respected

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|auto-close-tag|formulahendry|0.4.2|
|html-tag-wrapper|hwencc|0.1.5|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.3|
|font-awesome-codes-html|medzhidov|0.0.7|
|theme-oceandeep|pierrenel|0.0.1|
|view-in-browser|qinjia|0.0.5|;

I created an HTML file.  In the head element I put a <base> element (as per https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/base ), much like this:
\<base href=".."\>
(This is a relative link on purpose)

Elsewhere, in the body, I put a hyperlink like this:
\<a href="OtherDoc.html"\>other doc\</a\>

When I hold down control and click on the 'other doc' link VS code it attempts to open the OtherDoc.html in the same directory that my HTML page is in (i.e., it attempt to open it like any other file).

**It would be awesome if VSCode instead tried to open ../OtherDoc.html (i.e., it opened the file the same way the web browser will open the file).**

data.title: C++, No Type highlighting (except for fundamental types) on Linux
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 3.10.0-514.21.2.el7.x86_64
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|code-gnu-global|austin|0.2.2|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.4|
|cmake|twxs|0.0.17|;


Also I would like to note that I've already resolved the "GLIBC 2.18 dependency" using the suggested workaround : https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-cpptools/issues/19#issuecomment-248595508
And that the built-in types are highlighted!
---
Steps to Reproduce:

1.
```
#include <string>

std::string s; // not highlighted
```
2. custom
```
#include <stdint.h>

typedef int8_t   int8;
int8 test; // int8   is not highlighted
```
Built-in types are highlighted though!
What has to be done to get all types highlighted  ?

data.title: FileSystemWatcher fires on user settings file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Watch files with `workspace.createFileSystemWatcher('**');`
2. Change a user setting
3. Observe that there is a file system watcher event on the user config file `"c:\Users\...\AppData\Roaming\Code\User\settings.json"`

To me this doesn't make sense as it is not documented and also as there is a special event for listening to configuration changes. I wasn't successful in debugging this and the code I looked at (the watcher code) seems to take the workspace root as watching root so I'm not sure where this comes from.

data.title: VSCode installation name in Windows (and perhaps for other OS)
data.body:
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

I noticed that the Windows installer's name is now `VSCodeSetup-ia32-1.13.1` and `VSCodeSetup-ia32-1.14.0-insider`.

I particularly do not remember seeing some installer with 'ia32' or 'ia64'.

It would be better to change to:

 - X32: `VSCodeSetup1.13.1`:x: or `VSCodeSetup` :white_check_mark:  / `VSCodeSetup-insider`  :white_check_mark:
 
 _Since we can install VSCodeX32 on Windows X64_
 
 - X64: `VSCodeSetup1.13.1_x64` :x: or `VSCodeSetup_x64` :white_check_mark: or `VSCodeSetup` :white_check_mark: / `VSCodeSetup-insider` :white_check_mark: or `VSCodeSetup-insider_X64` :white_check_mark: 
 
 _There are programs that do not even show the architecture. Then he would not think it strange not to show. Since the size of the installer varies, the 'X64' is greater than 'X32', the vast majority (or total)._
 
 Load the version number or not? I am not for or against, but I would vote for not to bring. When smaller the better. (Except for something very specific.)
 
 See the installation of SQL Server, Service Pack for Windows and Microsoft Office, they bring 'X32 and X64' instead of 'ia'.

data.title: autoIndent doesn't handle indented wrapped TS lines well
data.body: ```ts if (a) { b = `foo` + `bar`; } ``` Put cursor after `}` and press enter: Ran into this while changing some terminal code, specifically: ```ts if (fgColor) { css += `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm { color: ${fgColor}; }` + `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm:not(.xterm-cursor-style-underline):not(.xterm-cursor-style-bar).focus .terminal-cursor,` + `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm:not(.xterm-cursor-style-underline):not(.xterm-cursor-style-bar):focus .terminal-cursor { background-color: ${fgColor} }` + `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm:not(.focus):not(:focus) .terminal-cursor { outline-color: ${fgColor}; }` + `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm.xterm-cursor-style-bar .terminal-cursor::before,` + `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm.xterm-cursor-style-underline .terminal-cursor::before { background-color: ${fgColor}; }` + `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm.xterm-cursor-style-bar.focus.xterm-cursor-blink .terminal-cursor::before,` + `.monaco-workbench .panel.integrated-terminal .xterm.xterm-cursor-style-underline.focus.xterm-cursor-blink .terminal-cursor::before { background-color: ${fgColor}; }`; } ```

data.title: Typescript intellisense and autocomplete not working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.16|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.62|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.4|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.12.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.9.0|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.4.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install vscode
2. Use typescript 2.4.0
3. Use a tsconfig.json file in root directory
4. Autocomplete and intellisense does not work for typescript

I have tried:

- Reload Window

- Reload Typescript project

- Restart computer

- Remove all extensions except for tslint

- Completely uninstall vscode and reinstalled - delete application, delete ~/.vscode, and delete $HOME/Libraries/Application Support/Code


My tsserver logs looks like this where it is erroring:

> Info 9    Search path: /path/to/project/src/modules
Info 10   Config file name: /path/to/project/tsconfig.json
Info 11   Loading  from /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js/../../.. (resolved to /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/node_modules)
Info 12   Failed to load module: {}
Info 13   Loading  from  (resolved to /path/to/project/node_modules)
Info 14   Failed to load module: {}
Info 15   Couldn't find  anywhere in paths: /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/typescript/lib/tsserver.js/../../..,

This folder doesn't exist:

> /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/node_modules/node_modules

tsconfig.json file: 
 
```
{
    "compileOnSave": false,
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es6",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "declaration": false,
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        "experimentalDecorators": true,
        "baseUrl": "",
        "typeRoots": [
            "node_modules/@types"
        ],
        "lib": [
            "es2016",
            "es2017"
        ]
    }
}
```

tsconfig.app.json file: 

```
{
    "extends": "../tsconfig.json",
    "compilerOptions": {
        "outDir": "../dist",
        "sourceMap": true,
        "baseUrl": "",
        "types": []
    },
    "exclude": [
        "**/*.spec.ts"
    ]
}
```

I noticed there is a ticket open for this here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24655

I thought maybe some tsserver logs might help, and it's in a mac environment so it could be slightly different.

This project works on other computers, and other projects work on this computer with identical tsconfig and tslint files. 

Intellisense for other languages is working, it is only missing in ts files.

data.title: Emmet 2.0:  "Wrap with Abbreviation" messes up formatting

data.title: Incorrect changing of name when pasting a file to the same folder

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|ssh|chrmarti|0.0.2|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|CppSnippets|hars|0.0.11|
|spacegray-vscode|ionutvmi|1.2.3|
|sublime-babel-vscode|joshpeng|0.2.5|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.62|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.4|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file called `dm1981-08-26.fm.johngates.1.flac1644.example.txt`
2. Right click -> Copy. Same folder -> Paste.
3. A new file called `dm1981-08-26.fm.johngates.2.flac1644.example.txt` is created.

Expected:

- A file called `dm1981-08-26.fm.johngates.1.flac1644.example.1.txt` to be created instead

What's probably happening here:

- The `johngates.1` is found, and incremented to `johngates.2`. It should check just before the extension instead.

|theme-material-theme|jprestidge|1.0.1|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.4|
|preview-vscode|searKing|1.1.5|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.8.1|

|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.3.2|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.7.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open terminal inside VSCode
2. Type "emacs -nw"
3. Type "Ctrl+C"
4. The message "<pause> is undefined" appears

---

If I type "Ctrl+C" when I use other program like vim, node, even emacs running with GUI from terminal, it works properly, but not with emacs without GUI..

data.title: Disable format on fix
data.body:
When using the fix menu in VSCode, it appears that formatters are run afterwards.

Could we add an option to disable this?

For example, formatting will occur upon running this fix:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/921609/27446655-65d667e8-574c-11e7-91de-37f5ac3edb38.png)
